utterances: And she of course had a strong interest in this in part because she was locked in a very tight re-election campaign that in fact went on for weeks after election day in the counting of the votes.
And very intense contest, and she was very interested in what the atmosphere might be right around election day.
Of course we're speculating here, but it's possible that an indictment of a group of Democratic officials right before the election could have hurt Democratic chances in that election in November.
Right.
Well, let's say that Iglesias does name both of them and makes these allegations.
What happens next?
We're going to open up a big can of worms.
In fact, I'd say several of them.
There will be investigations - ethics investigations in the House and the Senate if both these two members are named.

Ethics experts say that Domenici's conduct here may have violated Senate rules, which in general bar any communication between members of Congress and federal prosecutors about a specific ongoing criminal investigation.

Some of the standards for these cases in the past, and there of course have been several, include, for example, a particular senator calling and inserting himself - that was the term that was used in one investigation - inserting himself into the criminal process.
Let's go to Andrea(ph), Andrea with us from Santa Barbara.
So if this telephone call were interpreted in those terms, that could be very serious for Mr. Domenici.
Also, there will be an internal investigation within the Justice Department itself, in all likelihood.
And also, of course, media interest in all these cases is going to catch fire.
Right, and also, what about the other seven attorneys who were fired, what about them?
Well, we could hear quite a bit more about that.
Keep an eye on San Diego, where the U.S.
attorney indicted a Republican Congressman for bribery, and he is now serving in a federal prison.
That's Randy Duke Cunningham.
Ron Elving is NPR's senior Washington editor.
You can read his column, Watching Washington, at our Web site, npr.org.
Thank you very much, Ron.
Thank you, Madeleine.
Now, here's some of your comments.
He did not mention where he was writing from, but Leon Brown sent us an email in response to one of our roundtable topics this week.
He says, I didn't challenge New Orleans Mayor Ray Nagin's controversial chocolate city remark but rather made excuses for it.
He writes, Mr. Gordon left the impression that Nagin's racist remarks included a statement that the Mayor was wishing for a chocolate drink with white milk included.
The whiter press seemed to report that this later statement was a clarification and not part of the original speech.
Yet Mr. Gordon left the clear and false impression that these statements were part of the same tirade.
Mr. Brown continues to write, I have never heard such a benefit of the doubt be presented when it comes to the racist statement of others allowing them the luxury to revise and extend their remarks.
I find it curious that Mr. Gordon was not clear in describing the second statement as the clean up that it was.
Certainly, we all have our own political takes, but I think a moderator owes it to his audience to at least appear objective.
Listener Jim Smith writes, on January 12th, I was listening to News and Notes.
Melody Hobson made the remark, they're white.
They don't eat a lot of pork.
She said this in reference to the longevity of Supreme Court Justices.
I find this remark extremely racist.
I had no idea that NPR embraces or supports such people.
Well, Mr. Smith, actually, that remark wasn't made by Melody at all.
It was made by our roundtable panelist, economist Juliann Malveaux.
Here's Juliann's comment in context.
You be the judge.
(Soundbite of January 12th News & Notes)
John Roberts is 51 years old.
These folks, if they live right, you know, they white, they don't eat a lot of pork, they going to live awhile.
So, I mean, you know, if they live right, they're going to be there for another 30 years.
And so, if we're talking about 30 years of judicial input, we need to make sure that there's something bipartisan going on here.
And I think that that's what needs to be dealt with.
Whatever the committee does at the end of the day, we want something that's 60/40.
It's not about a filibuster.
It's about the Supreme Court being held to a higher standard.
We received this voicemail from P.J.
Joiner in Macon, Georgia.
She takes issue with a complaint we read in last week's letter segment.
The listener alleged that our roundtable panelist, Republican strategist Tara Setmayer, had been shouted down by fellow panelist George Curry, and that Mr. Curry was being rude.
Ms.
P.J.
JOINER (Caller): George Curry was not rude.
What he interjected was well within the realm of roundtable decorum.

George Curry cuts neither party any slack, so I think that comment was completely unfounded, and I am absolutely tired of Republicans maintaining, if you don't agree with us, then you're being rude or your being traitorous, or you're being un-American.
This is one of the few places on roundtable where you can hear an honest debate about politics in this culture, and I appreciate what your program does.
Yasmine(ph) Solomon called us from California.
She says while she appreciates the program, she thinks we don't go far enough in covering some issues.
I wish you would talk more about the death penalty and how racist and unjust it is and how there should be a moratorium on it.
There's a big movement in California for a moratorium because it is not just, it is not equal, and it is not fair.
We want to hear from you.
Call us with your comments at 202-408-3330.
Good, bad or ugly, we really do want to hear from you.
Tell us your name and where you're calling from.
Or you can email us.
Log on to npr.org and click on contact us.
Be sure to tell us how to pronounce your name.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Hundreds gathered today at the capitol building in Des Moines, Iowa to demand - let us vote.
The crowd wants an opportunity to overturn last week's decision from the state Supreme Court, which ruled that the state could not deny citizens marriage licenses based on sexual orientation.
Earlier this week, the legislature in Vermont voted to override that state governor's veto and passed what it called a Marriage Equality Act.
Some other states could soon consider similar legislation.
But while it might seem that the gay marriage tide is running one way, remember that just last November voters in California approved a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage.
Both sides are now mapping out tactics and strategy in any number of states.
Take the case to court, to the ballot box, to the legislature, work behind the scenes or on the airwaves.
Well, where is the battle where you live?
Our phone number: 800-989-8255, email us talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our Web site, that's at npr.org, click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Later in the program, a retired naval officer explains why he believes the threat from Somali pirates is overstated.
But first, the campaigns for and against same-sex marriage.
William Eskridge is a professor of law at Yale University, the author of ""Gay Marriage: For Better Or Worse."" He joins us today from member station in Roanoke, Virginia, WVTF.
Nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION.
Thank you, Neal.
Also with us is Maggie Gallagher, president of the National Organization for Marriage with us from a studio in Katonah, New York, and appreciate your coming in, as well.
Thanks.
And Maggie, let's start with you.
Iowa is in the news today from the anti-gay marriage campaign.
Where does it go next?
Yes I am, hi.
That's exactly it.
Our research has shown time and again that self-awareness is learnable.
But what so many people lack, you know, to overdramatize this a little bit, is a reckoning.
And I think that's what's happening in the media right now.
It's what happened with the executive you just mentioned, somebody to show them the truth or at least the truth of how they're seen in a way where they can't avoid it, where they have to face it.
That's Tasha Eurich.
She's an organizational psychologist who focuses on helping people become more self-aware.

And her latest book is called ""Insight: Why We're Not As Self-Aware As We Think, And How Seeing Ourselves Clearly Helps Us Succeed At Work And In Life."" She was kind enough to join us from the studios of Colorado Public Radio.
Tasha Eurich, thanks so much for speaking with us.
Thanks for having me.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Madeline Brand.
In New Orleans, a new use for the Audubon Zoo.
There are lots of people there this week not to see the animals, but to receive medical attention.
The city is using the zoo as a free medical clinic and thousands of people, many middle class, have come from around the state.
NPR's Audie Cornish reports.
It's not the first place you'd think to go for healthcare, but right now Barbara Blade says this feels like her only choice.
I was like oh, hell the zoo?
I couldn't believe they were doing this at a zoo.

Each day people like Blade line up as early as six a.m. at the Audubon Zoo for free meetings with medical specialists, like gynecologists and cardiologists or to register for simple physicals or eye exams.
Unidentified Man #1: I said if you're here for glasses only we've cut that area off.
They have 391 people already over there...
Gerry Addison is a couple rows back from Blade in a winding maze of metal barriers in the parking lot.
Addison says since she left her home flooded last fall she's been splitting her pills in half.
I don't even know where my doctor is.
Truthfully I don't even know where the physician is.
I need to get a prescription filled and I don't even know where he is.
Even if she could find her doctor Addison says she's currently unemployed and without healthcare and hasn't signed up for anything while she's trying to get back on her feet.
If you don't have a medical card you have to go to the local hospital and you wait for hour and hours and hours and hours, because there's so many people that need the attention.
If it's not an emergency and you go-- say for instance I need to get a prescription filled if I went to the emergency room I'm taking time of somebody who that has a dire emergency.
With city area medical centers closing after the storm the number of hospital beds in New Orleans is down from 53,000 to 15,000 and metro area clinics are bulging with patients.
And just like grocery stores and other businesses in the city, many pharmacies and doctor's offices are still closed.

The doctors here come from around the country, organized by a group called Remote Area Medical, which usually brings volunteer doctors and nurses into areas like the Appalachians for similar style clinics.
At the Audubon the open air oral surgery tent is down past the elephant exhibit and physicals take place behind curtains and wire at an administration hall.
Unidentified Man #2: Well, your blood pressure's really high.
It's 174 over 114, so that might be contributing to the headache.
Ms.
MONICA BARRELON(ph) (Receiving free healthcare): Yeah, because I didn't have medicine.
Unidentified Man #2: How come you're out of your medicine?
Did your doctor leave town or...
I can't find my doctor.
I can't find any doctor.
Unidentified Man #2: You can't find any doctor?
Ok.
